#Text=To read this documentation, you must turn JavaScript on.
#Text=Install and Configure PostgreSQL for Cloudera Software
#Text=Note: The following instructions are for a dedicated PostgreSQL database for use in production environments, and are unrelated to the embedded
#Text=PostgreSQL database provided by Cloudera for non-production installations.
#Text=To use a PostgreSQL database, follow these procedures.
#Text=For information on compatible versions of the PostgreSQL database, see Database Requirements.
#Text=If you already have a PostgreSQL database set up, you can skip to the section Configuring and Starting the PostgreSQL
#Text=Server to verify that your PostgreSQL configurations meet the requirements for Cloudera Manager.
#Text=Make sure that the data directory, which by default is /var/lib/postgresql/data/, is on a partition that has sufficient free space.
#Text=Cloudera Manager supports the use of a custom schema name for the Cloudera Manager Server database, but not the CDH component databases (such as Hive, Hue, Sentry, and so on).
#Text=If you want to install a different version, you can use zypper search
#Text=postgresql to search for an available supported version.
#Text=Hue in CDH 6 requires version 2.5.4 or higher of the psycopg2 Python package for connecting to a PostgreSQL database.
#Text=The psycopg2 package is automatically installed as a dependency of Cloudera Manager Agent, but the version installed is often lower than 2.5.4.
#Text=If you are installing or upgrading to CDH 6 and using PostgreSQL for the Hue database, you must install psycopg2 2.5.4 or higher on all Hue hosts as
#Text=Make sure that you have installed Python 2.7.
#Text=You can verify this by running the following commands:
#Text=Note: If you are making changes to an existing database, make sure to stop any services that use the database before continuing.
#Text=By default, PostgreSQL only accepts connections on the loopback interface.
#Text=You must reconfigure PostgreSQL to accept connections from the fully qualified domain names (FQDN) of the hosts
#Text=hosting the services for which you are configuring databases.
#Text=If you do not make these changes, the services cannot connect to and use the database on which they depend.
#Text=Make sure that LC_ALL is set to en_US.UTF-8 and initialize the database as follows:
#Text=Edit pg_hba.conf, which is usually found in /var/lib/pgsql/data or /etc/postgresql/<version>/main.
#Text=If the default pg_hba.conf file contains the following line:
#Text=then the host line specifying md5 authentication shown above must be inserted before this ident line.
#Text=Failure to do so may cause an authentication error when running the scm_prepare_database.sh script.
#Text=You can modify the contents of the md5 line shown above to support different configurations.
#Text=want to access PostgreSQL from a different host, replace 127.0.0.1 with your IP address and update postgresql.conf, which is typically
#Text=found in the same place as pg_hba.conf, to include:
#Text=Configure settings to ensure your system performs as expected.
#Text=Update these settings in the /var/lib/pgsql/data/postgresql.conf or /var/lib/postgresql/data/postgresql.conf file.
#Text=Settings vary based on cluster size and resources as follows:
#Text=Small to mid-sized clusters - Consider the following settings as starting points.
#Text=If resources are limited, consider reducing the buffer sizes and checkpoint segments further.
#Text=tuning may be required based on each host's resource utilization.
#Text=For example, if the Cloudera Manager Server is running on the same host as other roles, the following values may be acceptable:
#Text=max_connection - In general, allow each database on a host 100 maximum connections and then add 50 extra connections.
#Text=You may have to increase the system
#Text=resources available to PostgreSQL, as described at Connection Settings.
#Text=Note: The checkpoint_segments setting is removed in PostgreSQL 9.5 and higher, replaced by min_wal_size and max_wal_size.
#Text=release notes provides the following formula for determining the new settings:
#Text=Large clusters - Can contain up to 1000 hosts.
#Text=Consider the following settings as starting points.
#Text=max_connection - For large clusters, each database is typically hosted on a different host.
#Text=In general, allow each database on a host 100 maximum
#Text=You may have to increase the system resources available to PostgreSQL, as described at Connection Settings.
#Text=This requires that the operating system can allocate sufficient shared memory.
#Text=See PostgreSQL information on Managing Kernel Resources for more information on setting kernel resources.
#Text=This value is derived from the shared_buffers value.
#Text=Setting wal_buffers to be approximately 3% of shared_buffers up to a maximum of approximately 16 MB is sufficient in most cases.
#Text=Guide recommends values between 32 and 256 for write-intensive systems, such as this one.
#Text=Note: The checkpoint_segments setting is removed in PostgreSQL 9.5 and higher, replaced by min_wal_size and max_wal_size.
#Text=release notes provides the following formula for determining the new settings:
#Text=Configure the PostgreSQL server to start at boot.
#Text=Note: chkconfig may not be available on recent Ubuntu releases.
#Text=You may need to use Upstart to configure PostgreSQL
#Text=to start automatically when the system boots.
#Text=For more information, see the Ubuntu documentation or the Upstart
#Text=Create databases and service accounts for components that require databases:
#Text=Activity Monitor (if using the MapReduce service in a CDH 5 cluster)
#Text=The databases must be configured to support the PostgreSQL UTF8 character set encoding.
#Text=Record the values you enter for database names, usernames, and passwords.
#Text=The Cloudera Manager installation wizard requires this information to correctly connect to these databases.
#Text=Create databases for each service you are using from the below table:
#Text=You can use any value you want for <database>, <user>, and <password>.
#Text=following examples are the default names provided in the Cloudera Manager configuration settings, but you are not required to use them:
#Text=Record the databases, usernames, and passwords chosen because you will need them later.
#Text=For PostgreSQL 8.4 and higher, set standard_conforming_strings=off for the Hive Metastore and Oozie databases:
#Text=After completing the above instructions to install and configure PostgreSQL databases for Cloudera software, continue to Step 5: Set up
#Text=the Cloudera Manager Database to configure a database for Cloudera Manager.
